description.text: My printer came with an allen wrench to calibrate the print bed with, so of course I designed a thing to stick on the side of the printer that would hold said wrench. Designed in OpenSCAD, source file attached.
LucindaWe: LION GO RAAOOORW!!!!!

These new snap pins are meant to address the deficiencies of my previous pin library. These are much easier to insert, more tolerant of different printer calibrations, and stick better to the build platform.   
You can include this library in your OpenSCAD designs, or use customizer to export pins and holes for use with other programs.   
UPDATE: I added thin fins to the holes, which create slits when differenced. These fool slicers into making webs that strengthen the conical end of the hole. They greatly improve strength for vertically-oriented holes, and can be turned off in other situations if desired.

You can make either free or fixed holes, to allow rotation or not. I always recommend greasing the pins (I use white lithium grease, but I'm sure almost anything would work). It makes them easier to insert and remove, and allows them to turn much more freely without squeaking.   
The only part of these pins that are meant to fit tightly are the ends of the snaps. Since these parts are flexible, they work with different printer tolerances. All rigid parts of the pins are significantly smaller than the holes, ensuring ease of insertion.

title: Scythe RC Wing Motor Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Crash Test Hobbies' Scythe kit comes with a foam and mica motor mount. It doesn't look very good, leaves a large empty space in the V of the trailing edge of the wing, and doesn't line up well with the wing.
My motor mount automatically lines up in the deep V of the trailing edge of the wing and attaches securely on three different planes. I have even designed in hot glue spots that will direct excess glue away from the mount while attaching the mount to the plane for a secure fit.
According to my sort-of-accurate kitchen scale, CTH's motor mount weighs in around 2 grams and this version my my motor mount weighs in at 3 when printed in PLA with 100% infill. The model is strong enough to be flown as a park flyer in this configuration.
I've designed the hole pattern to work with the Blue Wonder motor.

title: Anet mainboard cover with reset button mosfet attachment and optional 30mmm fan duct

description.text:
I finally got my mosfet after a month so I made a cover with reset button that works great feels just like lcd screen buttons when pressed, just press it lightly and hear it click.. make sure the button slides in smoothly remove all excess filament on button and channel and ur good togo the button is offset 0.25 from the hole so if ur machine is calibrated well there should be minimal post processing.. And the photos of my cover is different from the stls up I modified a few things like heatsinks holes were backwards as well as the anet text and I moved the mosfet spot more to the left for easier assembly its all good now..PS I also cut the plastic spacers that came with the anet in half cause they didn't need that much space and unless u have 40- 50mm m3 screw ur gonna need to tap the screw into the plastic with a 3mm tap or just screw them in by hand with out the board connected first and wiring and mosfet should be instated first to make it easier. The fan duct just sits in between the board and cover
ENjoy

title: Trinus Heated Build Plate Cable Helper

description.text:
The Kodama Trinus is a gem of a little 3D printer -- but it's got a glaring weak spot in the form of the cable for its heated build plate. Or more accurately, the lack of stress relief provided to the cable for its heated build plate.

This little item is a stress relief sleeve -- put it on the build plate end of the troublesome cable, use one small zip tie to fasten it to the build plate, use another small zip tie to fasten the sleeve to the cable, and you're done.

Many printers have trouble producing fine detail on a single small item like this. So when the time comes for printing, I'd recommend you print 3 or 4 of these, spread out on your printer's build plate. This allows each layer to cool properly before the next one starts. Of course, you could just set your slicer's minimum layer time to a larger-than-usual number -- but that wouldn't give you spare parts!

Notes:

You'll get the best results if you print this on-end, rather than laying down flat. Using support is good for some of the fine detail.

comments.text: 2017-06 and the cables now have heatshrink over the ends (so the cable diameter is now 7.5mm). Also, the "new" cables width at the point you would use a cable tie can vary or be irregularly shaped if the sheath underneath the heatshrink doesn't reach the cable tie position.

comments.text: Can you reach 100°C on your heatbed? How many AMPs is your psu?
comments.author: Alex76

comments.text:
Hello Alex
I'm using 12v/20amp psu. I always use a realy to power the 200x300mm bed. (12V 87A 40 amp car relay) It takes only 3 minutes to reach 60 deg. I have never tested it for 100 deg, but I think it is possible. I did a test just now from 20 to 80 deg takes 6 minutes, but I don't trust my simple 1,5 mm glass (from a clips picture frame) to take on 100 deg, and I always use PLA-plast, so for me no need for more than 55-60 deg. I use hair spay on the glass and I'm very pleased with the result. I made a bigger printer with 2x200x300 beds. On this printer I used 12v 30amp psu and the same relay for the 400x300 bed.
comments.author: Alex76

comments.text: Thanks, I don't tried yet to use the relay (I've one at home) ...tried only with onboard mosfet
comments.author: Choose

comments.text: It is easy to use a "87A" relay. From the onboard mosfet you connect "the bed" to "85" and "86" on the relay. Then one leader goes direct from the psu to the bed and the other from the psu to "30" on the relay and from "87" on the relay to the bed. Most onboard mosfet can not take more than 11amp and a 200x300 bed in 12V can overload your mosfet.
comments.author: Alex76

author: WillandMrData2

description.text: This is a simple track, meant to go with my Printable Carriage model. Unlike other printable rails I've seen, this one is designed to be printed horizontally. This takes advantage of the grooves formed by the lines laid down by a 3D Printer instead of working against them, as was the case for the rail originally intended to be used by this carriage. This should be a simple print for just about any printer on the market, and is designed to be easily linked along a quarter inch threaded rod using nuts trapped in to properly align them. These two components are intended to serve as a sort of base to a wide variety of printable assemblies, and expect extensions to this platform in the near future.

comments.text: i am using a da vinci AIO that i have made a new fan housing for the da vinci my printer had 2 main problems when i purchased it first with abs i was getting layers that was accapitable to 3d printing standards was not up to my standards because they would shear realy easly so they had no strength and 2 would not run any thing other than xyz filament with out lots of clogs what i discovered about the clogs was a defective fan plug that was making the fan intermittent after repairing that issue it did not solve the layer issue so i created a new fan housing that forces the air down over the cooling fins of the extruder that solved both jams and the added benefit  and i have had arguments with others on this issue people have ben adding layer fans to keep the upper layers cool for more even layers what i have found is the exact oppisot of that practice the upper layers are already cooler than the bottom layers so that the filament is just being layed on the layer and not melting into the layer making it not realy adhear what i found is the exact opisot of that philosophy the layer that it is being layed on has to be hot enough for the layers to melt into each other my fan design solves this by forcing the hot air down to the part keeping the upper layers warm enough so that the layers are not just being layed down but are melting into each other creating a realy smooth surface and solving the shearing problem

title: Air Blow Gun Nozzle for blow gun from Harbor Freight
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: So after creating a trigger/handle for the Harbor Freight air blow gun, I decided to create a nozzle for it to have the more airflow forced out and wider cover area when cleaning computers. Printed in PLA at 0.2mm layer height. I did not wanted to squash the nozzle tip to make it narrower to achieve similar result. Used 7x1mm die to cut the thread on the nozzle as the original plan was to have it screwed onto it, was able to thread the nozzle on without cutting thread in the plastic (for tighter fit might reduce the tube diameter just a bit). Note that tube is about 1/4 inches in diameter, had to compromise because I couldn't find SAE tap & die set at the moment. Print one out and let me know how it goes as I am concerned how well it'll stay on the metal tube when the air is forced through smaller opening.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm or 0.3 mm

Infill:

20 - 30 used %

comments.text: If I understood your meaning, you could use 2 or 3 wraps of Teflon pipe tape to hold nozzle securely. Also, reduce the pressure when using it if you think its an issue, but I think it will be fine. I,we pressure tested a PLA 1/4in pipe at 117psi without failure.
comments.author: Pop4solar

comments.text: I just had some time messing around with this thing in the shop @ 150 PSI big tank and it stays on tube like a champ. Started to rotate a bit more freely, but not freely spins. Need to find something for the visual comparison to be more visible than the skin deformation on the hand from the air flow. Note the blow gun is cheap and its like I've seen are all rated to 90 PSI according to the sticker on its side.

title: Finger Cap Toothbrush Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Finger Cap Toothbrush Holder is designed to be an assistive product. Have you ever struggle with gripping or holding onto everyday items? If you have, you may be able to benefit from this product while brushing your teeth. This product will allow you to brush your teeth without holding onto your toothbrush. The product is composed of two caps, one for your finger and the other for you toothbrush. To use you simply put the preferred finger (suggested: index finger) into the 'finger cap', the finger cap is the smaller cap that is hallowed out. The other cap that is larger in length is the 'toothbrush cap', this cap will be used to hold your toothbrush so you will put the toothbrush into it. Once you have your finger cap on with the toothbrush cap resting on the outer side of your hand you can now use the product to brush your teeth without gripping the toothbrush.

title: "Spriya" - High Efficiency Anet A8 Fan Duct

description.text:
If you use this fan duct & think it makes your prints look better, don't forget to TIP! ;)

The story

I designed this fan duct as a 100% free & open source alternative to another one which was very good, but unfortunately it's license was preventing me from modifying it the way I see fit & share it freely.
So I started Blender, and made my own from scratch in a couple of days. One that I can share freely with the community, so anyone can use it, remix it or trash it - in any order ;)
The fan duct works very good for me, but I give you no warranty that it will work for you.

Highlights of this fan duct:

  • The most important: it's more effective compared to the semi-circular design, and A LOT more effective than the stock Anet A8 fan duct.
  • it's quieter, compared to the stock & the semi circular design
  • it does not block the view, and you can see your nozzle tip
  • it uses my own attachment design, and once it's inserted onto the fan, it's impossible to fall off. Forget about the tape or glue for securing your "always falling" fan duct.
  • it blows more air, compared to the other duct designs I tested. Instead of concentrating "on the tip of the nozzle", the air flow is wider, and separated at 2 flows at approximately 90 degrees. This way it cools wider area, even if the nozzle moves away from the "point of interest".
  • when mounted & tuned properly using PID Auto Tune (described below), it does not cool the heat block, and the temperature is very stable - plus/minus 0.5C.
  • VERY lightweight - just 3 grams, compared most of the other fan ducts which weigh 4-6 grams or more! So even if you find out it's trash, you've lost the material for just 1/6 3D Benchie or one calibration cube :)
  • open source design, made with open source software - I am releasing the original design in .blend format, which you can load in Blender and make modifications. You are then completely free to release any remixed designs you made! In fact, it will be great!
  • the mesh is relatively low-poly, so it's easy to edit in blender if you want to make your own adjustments.

Testing

I used the Marvin Key Chain as a test object - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:215703.
The print settings were as follows:

  • layer height 0.2mm
  • shell width 1.2mm
  • temperature 190C (PLA)
  • print speed 30mm/s outer shell, 60mm/s inner shell, 100mm/s travel
  • no infill
  • print acceleration 800mm/s^2, travel acceleration 1600mm/s^2
  • the objects "back" side was facing to the back of the printer (towards Y MIN), so it was prone to "sagging" on the lower layers (true for any spherical object).

Test Results

  • the stock fan duct - a lot of sagging on the back, and left/right sides of the model (terrible)
  • the "Semi-Circular" fan duct - some sagging on the back, and just 1-2 layers on one of the sides
  • "Spriya" design (this fan duct) - (almost) no sagging at all, with just two tiny irregularities - two "dots" on the back side of the model.
    Check out the photos to see a comparison.
    I have also tested with 3D Benchy - placed so the bow of the ship is facing to the right. The results were consistent, and in fact even better: sagging on bow with the stock fan duct (and some layer irregularities); just a little sagging with the semi-circular design; and absolutely no sagging or defects with "Spriya".

Tuning your heater using PID Auto Tune

This step is very important, so don't blame the fan duct if you have not performed it and you are getting bad results :)
Every time you install a new fan duct, it's highly recommended to perform the so-called "PID Auto Tune" procedure on your heat block. It's performed very easily - when your printer is cold, connect it to your PC, and start your preferred program that allows you to send GCODE commands directly to your printer. You can use Pronterface (http://www.pronterface.com/) or whatever you prefer (some slicers have this function built in).
Next, decide what's your preferred print temperature - in my case it's 190C.
You will also have to turn the fan ON.
Execute the following GCODE command to turn it on:

M106 S255

Now run the PID auto tune GCODE command (replace "190" with whatever temperature you use):

M303 E0 S190 C8

It will respond with
Info:PID Autotune start

Your printer will go through 8 cycles of heating / cooling, so it will take a couple of minutes.
In the end, you will get a response, that looks something like this:

bias: 164 d: 90 min: 188.73 max: 191.76
Ku: 37.70 Tu: 20.50
Classic PID
Kp: 22.62
Ki: 2.21
Kd: 57.96
Info:PID Autotune finished ! Place the Kp, Ki and Kd constants in the Configuration.h or EEPROM

Copy this response somewhere, otherwise it will quickly get lost in the idle "wait" messages.
Now go to your printer's Configuration -> Extruder menu, and set the control type to PID. Next, set the P value to match the Kp, I to match Ki, and D to match Kd.
Finally, save your settings to the EEPROM.
This is how it's done with the Repetier firmware. It should be almost the same with the stock Anet firmware, and similar with Skynet3D (Marlin)
When you have tuned your heater properly, the temperature will fluctuate by just plus/minus 0.5 - 1C and will be very stable.

Notes

  • Actually try it before starting to philosophize whether it's effective or not :)
  • Read below to find out the recommended print settings
  • To mount the fan duct, you have to loosen the screws of your fan a bit, insert the duct, and tighten them again.
  • The name "Spriya" is a Bulgarian dialect word, and means "strong wind", "vortex", "blizzard" etc ;) It's a joke.
  • Check out some of my other open source stuff at http://lokspace.eu
  • If you have problems slicing / printing the normal version, try the "thick walls" version - "Spriya - Anet A8 Fan Duct - Thick Walls.stl" found in the archive (it has 1.2mm walls, but it's still lightweight).

    Don't forget to post "I made one" photos! Your input is welcome!

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

I used Cura 2.4 to print this.
Check the pictures to see how you should lay the model down when printing (rotate it 90 degrees along the X axis, and allow supports - as shown on the fifth picture. Only the attachment part needs a bit of support, so you can set the "Support Overhang Angle" to something high like 80.
You also need to set the support placement to "everywhere", and support type to "concentric".
Support density of 15% works OK. Be careful when removing the supports afterwards!
Without support, the upper part of the attachment might sag a bit, but it will still work.

comments.text:
How far above tip of the nozzle can this fan be to be effective? I initially had it level with the nozzle but in some cases it would scrape.
I then screwed down the nozzle a bit so this is sitting maybe 1-2mm above. Occasionally stray strands (usually from support structures) get caught and dragged along. Doesn't usually compromise the print.
I'm still new to printing and I'm not exactly sure where these should be blowing. I see from above they shouldn't be blowing on the heat block (I assume that is the square metal block above the nozzle). But should they be blowing ON the nozzle, right below the nozzle, etc.

description.text:
This is my headphone holder design, I wanted something pretty minimal in my desk and didn't want to mess with supported parts or real bolts so everything here is 3dprinted. I have tried with both my ATHM50x and Sennheiser HD555 and works well for both.

This design should be fine for desks between 35 and 31mm thanks to the lower bolt, I have only tried with mine that is almost 35mm. If you want to use it in a different thickness desk just ask me, the design should be easy to tweak.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm (clamp, holder) // 0.1mm bolts

Infill:

30%

Notes:

These bolts are printed at 0.1mm due to their small size (7-8min), maybe the print works with 0.2mm but I haven't tried.

print_settings.Notes:: I'd print this thing with the protubances pointing upwards so flip the model 180 degrees. It's optimised for a 0.4mm nozzle and ABS is a great choice for the plastic.

description.text:
This is a push on protector for those of us using this thing in a hobby where there is a chance at damaging the large lens and glass. The extensions on the sorround are designed to just be out of shot at the top and bottom of the video when fitted properly. One side only is strengthened to help for flatter mounting.

Happy printing and flying!

No

No

0.2mm

I'd print this thing with the protubances pointing upwards so flip the model 180 degrees. It's optimised for a 0.4mm nozzle and ABS is a great choice for the plastic.

description.text: This is another fidget spinner to play with, it has been made to insert 4 608 ball bearings (skateboard ones)

This card shuffler is designed for a set of official poker card size cards (smaller size cards would work too).

This design can be printed on FFF & SLA style printers with a build volume of 130 x 130 x 130 mm.

UPDATE: August-21-2017
After recieving feedback from a couple testers, I made a version 2. The shuffler now has:

  • Increased max card size
  • A feet under the card holder for stability
  • Clips to hold the roller in place (Some people had it working without the clips)

However, there are still some things left to do:

  • Make a better connection between the stops and the bottoms

I Love to hear feedback from you!

UPDATE: July-5-2017
I have been improving the design, i decreased the angle of the rollers and adjusted some tolerances.
I would love to have it tested by someone other than me. If you would like to help me, please leave a message!

FlashForge

Printer:

Finder

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Yes

Varies by file

Varies by file

1x = M4x16 bolt
1x = M4x40 bolt
2x = M4 nuts
4x = O-ring (you can also use a rubber band, or a hot glue gun) for gripping to the 3d printed surface

author: robbycandra

title: Filter Case (4) for DJI Mavic Pro Lens Filters

description.text: This is designed to store up to four lens filters that fit the DJI Mavic Pro gimbal camera. It should fit most of the leading brands of aftermarket filters, except for DJI's own filters with their unique form factor.

Blender Booleans

First, I measured and modeled my own filters; these were Freewell's 4-pack. These are pretty typical of the ones I have seen, such as those from PolarPro and TACO-RC, but the exception is DJI's own offerings with an entirely different design.

Second, I mocked up the case I wanted, using Blender with heavy use of boolean modifiers. This lets me move different shapes around independently without committing myself to the final mesh topology.

Third, for the DJI logo, I imported an SVG and adjusted it slightly for better printability, and cut that into the case with another boolean modifier.

Fourth, export to STL and print a few iterations for experiments.

Updated: January 18th, 2018:

I have adjusted the design slightly and uploaded new files with a Showershelf2-name.
Two new models in 170 mm en 200 mm size.
The thickness of the model is slightly increased (to 5.5mm) for extra strength.
Also, the corner has a larger cutout for walls that have an uneven corner.

This is an easy to print shelf for your shower.
I designed this in OpenSCAD because most standard metal shower shelfs tend to be rather small.
Preferably, do not print this in standard PLA as PLA will not be able to withstand the temperature of hot water without warping.
I have printed this in PETG and it is holding up just fine, even when rinsing it of with hot tapwater (which usually is no more than 65-70 degrees Centigrade).

I have uploaded both a 200mm model (which I use) and a smaller 150 mm model.

No

0.1-0.2mm

Notes:

Print this in PETG, ABS, ASA.
Just remember that this shelf needs to have a reasonable temperature resistance.
So print it in PETG, ABS or ASA to make sure it will resist the hot water temperature it will be subjected to.

author: NetStorm

print_settings.Notes:: Run in Repitier Host and switch filament as needed.

description.text:
Needing to make several of these, I didn't want to spend a lot of time assembling them by hand. I decided to use the filament swapping technique to get the same full color look. It's true that the result is not flat on top, but the colors come out so crisp that I think it's a good trade off.

I took the separate parts and combined them so that each colored section was a different height.

I used the @pause command to get the pauses in, but this only works with repiter host, so you might need to switch to this control program for your actual prints. Details are in the Print Settings section.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Printed going from darkest to lightest (white to red to black) keeps the colors nice and crisp.

50% infill helps get the top of the object nice and smooth.

I also bumped up the extruder temperature in order to help get nice flat top layers.

In order to get the automatic pauses in my g-code, I identified the layer for each switch in my slicing program, exported to g-code and then modified the g-code using Notepad++.

Searching for each layer I added the following code:

G1 Z100
G1 E-100
@pause Change Filament

So that layer 14, in my case now looks like below:
; layer 14, Z = 2.7
G1 Z100
G1 E-100
@pause Change Filament
M105

Run in Repitier Host and switch filament as needed.

Coller chaque ensemble de pièces (la colle cyanoacrylate fonctionne bien)

description.text:
Disclaimer: I am not responsible for anything you do.

The problem:

Many a time I have needed to run a print well into the night, leaving me with two options. Leave the printer running all night or wake up at some ungodly hour to turn it off.

The solution:

Enable to printer to pull the plug on itself at the end of the print, in a reliable, simple to implement solution.

My printer started life as a Da Vinci 1.0, however it's now running an mks gen 1.4 board which has servo outputs. Your printer may differ.

For this, you will need:

A control board that has a servo output.

1 x R/C Relay such as https://littlebirdelectronics.com.au/products/pololu-rc-switch-with-relay-assembled

1 x r/c servo extension cable

1 x regular relay such as https://littlebirdelectronics.com.au/products/30a-horn-relay-spst

1 x momentary push button of your choice (hence forth known as the ignition button)

Please refer to the diagram how to wire this, if it doesn't make sense then you probably shouldn't be messing with your printer.

How it should work.

  • Power switch off, press ignition - it will power on, but then die when you release the ignition button, no bueno.

  • Power switch on, press ignition - it will power on, energize the main relay and keep it on even after you release the ignition button.

To kill it either:

  • Power switch off - duh...

  • Insert m280 p1 s2000 in your end gcode.

(where p is the number of your servo -1, eg 0 is servo 1, 1 is servo 2 etc) I had a Z-probe on p0, hence why this is p1. This will switch the rc servo, which will interrupt the circuit keeping the main relay closed, which in turn will interrupt the circuit keeping the power supply on.

It's like the worlds most boring game of domino's.

Possible issue:

  • The mks gen 1.4 board 'maintains consciousness' if connected by usb even if the main power is out. It's a good idea to call m280 p1 s0 after the kill command to ensure rc servo/relay/thing releases. Otherwise if your printing off a sd card with no usb connected, everything should reset once power cuts out.

  • For some reason, sometimes my m280 p1 s2000 is ignored, I found if you call m280 p1 s0 before hand this should't be an issue.

To be safe, put this in your end gcode.

m280 p1 s0 - rc relay closed, which should be default option
m280 p1 s2000 - rc relay open, kill everything
m300 - beep just to buy some time and make sure everything is thoroughly killed.
m280 p1 s0 - reset rc relay in case usb power is present. (printer will stay dead until you press the ignition button).

BTW you may need to make a couple easy changes in your firmware (I'm using marlin) if you haven't already enabled the servos.

P's,

The screw posts for the r/c relay servo broke when I tried to screw it in, ended up just using double sided tape instead.

Big servo uses a m3 screw, rc servo 2mm self taping screws I had lying around.

description.text:
The Clip-On Lens Cap Keeper can hold ANY SIZE OF LENS CAP!

Simply slide your camera strap into the alligator teeth of the 3d printed clip, snap it closed and you're good to go! Pinch to open the clamp and insert any size lens cap!

There are multiple versions available:

  • Medium: This version will work for most camera and camera bag straps.
  • Tight: In case you have a very thin camera strap.
  • Large: In case you have a thick camera or camera bag strap.
  • CLOSED: Means that the pincher at the end (that holds the lens caps) is much closer together, these can be used to hold micro-fiver cloths and other things that are not as thick as a lens cap. NOTE: These "CLOSED" versions may not work for lens caps depending on what type of plastic you print with and how flexible it is! If printing in PLA, go with the regular version, not the "CLOSED" version.

Has been tested with lens cap sizes: 20.6mm-145mm and all seem to fit well so far.

This is a drawer which fits in the cubby below the main center screen of a Tesla to prevent your stuff from flying out when you punch it. I know it fits in a left-hand drive Model S and Model X. It has compartments for sunglasses, folded napkins, and membership / parking cards.

I have made some improvements after living with it a while. The latest version allows cards to sit at a more inclined angle so they don't cause the drawer to push so hard on the lip of the cubbie. It has blocks that keep the cards centered in the slot. It also allows sunglasses to be installed so that the arms don't appear on the front. Tesla Drawer Print XL 3 is 8.25"x4.75"x1.75" and fully fits the width of the cubby. Because 8" is the limit on some printers, I've left up my original Tesla Drawer Print which is 7.75"x4.75"x1.75". It should sit right behind the lip on the front edge of the shelf.

I put up one without the sunglass divider as well. There is a narrow 7.75" version for those with an 8" print limitation and another XL which is 8.25" wide to fill the cubby.

Apparently, This currently only fits Left Hand Drive Teslas. If someone can send me the size of the RHD cubby, I'll upload one that fits there as well. Thanks.

This is a photo of the original drawer. The updated one drops the internal sides of the card slots and the ends of the sunglass divider. This is a photo of the original drawer. The updated one drops the internal sides of the card slots and the ends of the sunglass divider.

description.text: Print Head cables are too short, and the cable management is inadequate, leading to the cable being dragged across the work surface and hanging up on the build plate, and even getting caught on the work in progress. Especially when printing a large object that uses up most of the work area... 12 hours into a print is a bad time for the cables to get caught and cause a stall. After putting up with it for 3 years I finally broke down and did some much-needed mods. Finally replaced all carriages with Lawsy's modded carriage, added an X-Motor cable guide and cooling fan, and now a cable guide for the print head. I have run the printer sufficiently to make sure the cable guide has full travel and does not bind during operation, though I have not actually run the cables through it yet, as that will require lengthening all the cables to about double their current length, as they are all way too short. To mount the motor bracket, discard the heat sink on the back of the feed stepper motor... I can't imagine what good it does, as the cooling fan will do a better job of cooling the feed motor if it blows directly onto it, rather than onto a heat sink. This motor does not get very hot anyway. The endpoint attachment simply slides onto the frame at the back of the printer, and the wires get fed through the space between the frame and the endpoint to keep them away from the Y-carriage shaft. I'll post pictures as I rewire the print head. printed with PLA at 205 degrees . There are 20 links in the .STL file, and you will need all of them. Included original .RSDOC (DesignSpark Mechanical) files in case you want to mod.

comments.text:
Sure! Rods are the right thing to do but I'm with you on the "Good enough for government work" thing.
I have a 40W heater cartridge for my E3D v6 hot end, these are the ones with the red wires. At 12V, that would draw about 3.5 Amps. I usually just use the wire that came with the hot end. But you should be OK with 16 AWG wire.
I use this as a guideline to figure out what wire gauge to use: http://www.powerstream.com/Wire_Size.htm
comments.author: RCFerguson

comments.text: OK, wiring is done...it looks nice and neat, though the cables really do fill up the cable guide. I might make it a little bigger if I was to do it again, but honestly, this seems to work really well. I stuffed all the cables into some left-over plastic conduit an drilled a couple holes in the back to run the cable ties through. The conduit makes the whole bundle a bit thicker, and I really had to crank on the cable ties so the conduit wouldn't rub on the Y-axis drive rod (or whatever that thing is called). It would probably be just as well to not put the cables into the conduit, but it does look tidy. Doesn't seem to bind or catch anywhere, and no more dragging cables across the work surface. Yay!

remixed_from.author: idea_beans
remixed_from.title: Adjustable Filament Holder (which may also be used as pulleys)

description.text:
I found a pretty nice looking filament spool holder, but many people complained because the support required is very difficult to remove. This design should print with zero support, but requires assembly after printing. The amount of each piece needed to print is included in the part name, and assembly should be pretty self-explanatory. Please leave any feedback, good or bad! This was printed by a150587 with the fixed pin design and it is confirmed to be working! UPDATE
12/27/13 Made it simpler by implementing a "snap" pin, now two more regular washers are required but the number of unique pieces was reduced from 6 to 4. 1/2/14 Happy New Year! Included fixed pin design courtesy of a150587. Thanks! NOTE. The source file for the pin is for the old pin design, which does not work as is. 1/15/14 Modified wheel design, it should print much nicer now.

In order to build this, print the designated amount of each piece. Base piece must be rotated to upright position first. The amount required of each piece is stated in the stl file. ABS recommended, but PLA should work just as well. Sparse inflill (10-20%) should work without a problem, print with more shells for better durability. Assembly
  • Place the base piece on a surface, flat side down.
  • Push the pin through one of the holes, the flat head should be on the outside of the base unit, not in-between the two arms with holes.
  • Place a washer on the pin.
  • Place a wheel on the pin.
  • Place another washer on the pin.
  • Push the pin through the other hole of the base piece.
  • Add one last washer to the pin. Apply glue or use a wire if needed to secure the pin in place (should not be required with a well calibrated printer)
  • Repeat steps 2-7 for the other hole of the base unit.
  • Repeat steps 1-8 for the other base unit.
  • Profit.

comments.text: I think you have a mistake in the number of washers needed... I do believe 12 are needed, but in the filename it says 10 are needed. Which is correct?

description.text:
This is a small case for Lee hart's Z80 membership Card computer. It's designed to fit in an Altoids Mint tin. With the addition of the SIO/RAM/CP/M card, the Altoids tin was no longer tall enough to accomodate the stack of cards. So I designed one, based on the Altoids can, with cut outs for the Micro SD Card, and the FTDI serial connection :)

It's a great little retro computer project. :)

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

15%

Notes:

because there are not a lot of details i chose to print at .3mm instead of the usual .2mm layer height. but feel free to print at either. :) Printed it in PLA, also when installing the 3 card stack into the case, first put the SIO card, on the Z80 card, tilt and insert those two first, then you stack the front panel card onto those once they are in the case... :)

to remove the cards from the case, remove the front panel board first, then tilt the other two as you remove them... a bit tricky, but I figured it out, so can you :)

Cheers. :) I hope you guys like it. it's a small audience for this device. :)

description.text:
The Buzz Box is a complete kit. Its awesome for learning the basics to program and play with an Arduino UNO R3.
"Like US" https://www.facebook.com/badbrick The "kit" is fully assembled and works as a basic motion detector unit. If you want to learn programming, or get your kids excited about what a computer and electronics can do, this is a great way to start. This kit requires it all. You need to get all the Arduino IDE set up, all the electronics connected. You need to write the code, compile it, upload it, and waaaaala. Magic happens.
http://www.badbrick.com/content/badbrick-buzz-box-complete-kit For the most part its pretty simple if you know what you're doing.. For kids, its using a computer, having fun, and make something move. They learn a ton of stuff in the process without realizing it. They will want to know more.
If you want to make one yourself. Print the files. Our Kit includes:
  • Arduino UNO R3
  • Parallax PIR sensor, with extension wires.
  • Piezo buzzer, with extension wires.
  • LED
  • (2) 9 Volt batteries wired in parallel, with the Arduino Power plug adapter. This is the Power Pack for the Buzz Box.
  • A pre loaded basic motion sensing sketch and the downloadable source code.

In MakerWare, I modify the "Medium" settings: Quality: Layer Height = 0.18
Infill: 15%
Shells: 2
For the battery base box, Arduino + Sensor Mount base, and top cover. All other defaults are the same. Building the Buzz Box. Print all the parts.. Wiring up the Echo Box is pretty easy. The Arduino just sits in the base mount. The PIR Sensor just mounts in the end. I solider on some short solid jumper wires to the PIR, pins and plug them in. The Piezo buzzer, with extension wires mounts in the small hole at the top. The LED plugs in the sides, its wires should extend right down to pin 13 Hopefully that explained it all. Some of the pictures above also show the assembly. If you have any questions or suggestions please feel free to comment.

author: islandarmor

description.text:
Low profile Nikon hot shoe adapter to Sony/Minolta flash.

Printed at 40% speed. Handle printed better at 20%.

No electrical connection option provided with V1.

V2 adapter with electrical connection option. No TTL. Can be used with a flash fill. My camera works best in most cases with the light on continuously.

Cleaned holes with #52 drill bit. Used #14 bare copper wire for the pins. A slight friction fit is optimal. Slight cuts with a diagonal cutter will help this.
The pins should protrude slightly above the print before sliding the flash head on.
I rounded the pin ends before the final install. Mount the build, insert the pins and then the flash.

Check to see if every thing is pushed all the way in. May require some movement to seat the pins.

I believe it can be purchased on line as a C-S1 Hot Shoe Converter Adapter
for Canon/Nikon Camera to a Sony/Minolta Flash.

comments.text:
Thank you very much!
Model perfectly fits both camera and flash. Though its connection became a bit loosy after number of inserts, adapter can be used with proper caution. I tested Aluminum foil instead of wires, and it works great without scratches.

description.text:
When you have a cylinder vase with a big mouth but you get only one flower to be put into it, the picture is not so nice.

Well, you can buy more flowers, but the whole picture becomes noisy. Or you can give up your old favorite vase for a new smaller one, but I guess it is not the best choice.

My option is to put a cover on the mouth of the vase, so as to make a balance between them.

The cover looks like a wave, the right part of it is higher than the surface of the vase mouth, while the left sinks into the vase. The flower could be put through the hole.

For dimension of the vase i used, its mouth has an outer diameter of 122mm and an inner diameter of 107mm.

A docking sound bar for a Nexus 7 V.1 with case. It should fit a Nexus 7 Version 2, but I do not have one to experiment with.   
The Purpose is to amplify your Nexus 7 speakers; while it does do this, there is a bit of "tiny" sound that I hope to work out with materials/ infill. I have not included a charging port in this version as I wanted the sound to be contained, and funnelled specifically to the front.   
Printed at .2mm, 20% infill, and no support. Currently experimenting with PLA/ABS/Nylon, and T-Glass with various infill levels for changes in sound.   
Update: added a modified port for an Iphone 5; I have not tested it, but it should still fit.

I picked this design to remix because I wanted soup cups with handles. The Espresso coffee set by Medelis is a beauty to remix because of the curvature of the cups as well as the tray which fits the bottom of the cups perfectly. I also like the way Medelis tilts the four cups toward the center, effectively shifting the center of gravity, making the set easier to carry.

My initial goal was to remix a bird but I was frustrated trying to sculpt the beak of a hornbill on the original bird. I tried several ways for 2 hours. Then I came across Medelis' Espresso coffee set which reminded me of a real need -- to serve soup safely in aesthetically-pleasing cups. This time round, chiselling away at the top of the cups to make them shorter was easy. Also the curvature of the original cups were maintained.

title: Xiaomi Mi Band 2 replacement wrist band / chain
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
New Version available here

Magnetic, filament-fused Mi Band 2 replacement wrist band

Unfortunatly my original MiBand wristband just broke. I always wanted a band that looked more like that of a metal watch. So this is my replacement design.

What you need

  • 3D-Printer
  • Raw bits of 1.75mm filament
  • 4 magnets (6mm diameter x 3mm)
  • Superglue

Post your I Made One if you did.

Have fun printing | running | fusing | timeing | monitoring

Assembly

Connect as many links as you need to the ends of the shell. Stick small bits of raw filaments into the holes. Then connect the two magnetic endparts.
I heated up a thick needle with a lighter and poked in each end of the raw filament. By doing this the ends of the filament bit expanded and it couldn't fall out anymore.

Last but not least glue two magnets in each endpart

The individual links are fused together with raw bits of 1.75mm filament

I printed the set through http://www.printerstudio.com but you could use similar custom card-making websites or just print off the cards yourself on your own printer (if printing yourself make sure to use a thick enough paper with semi-gloss!)

Here is a collection of files to print and build muqarna style decorations. "Muqarba", - mocárabes in Spanish -, would be the Andalousi version of this genre, found in the Alhambra in Granada (sample in pics) and Sevilla Alcazar, from around the XIVth century. General name in English would be muqarna. The system is some kind of flexible 3D tessellation, mainly used in ceilings and arches. Three main forms in plan and around 8 forms in 3D, with simple combination rules, have the potential to generate complex forms and visual effects. Original pieces were either gypsum/plaster or wood.

Geometry of these files has been developed by Antonio Saseta, based on XVII C treatises by Diego López de Arenas and Fray Andrés de San Miguel. Even though some definite proportions model is given by these authors, looking in situ to existing examples one can tell the geometry can be used in quite flexible ways, respecting the basic plan and "interface" between the pieces rules.

This is a work in progress. Files included are stls and a Rhino working file. Stl files are approximately 1/5th of standard size seen in the main spaces of the Alhambra.

I will add asap a web page link with more info about the system.

Thsi work is being developed by the Fab Lab Sevilla network. We are studying to develop it further as some kind of construction kit game. If anyone would be interested to contribute, it would be really nice.

description.text: This is a modified version of Camiels Orca 0.4 Y-Axis Opto Holder, modified to allow it to be put on without taking the axis apart.

Pretty self-explanatory.
The opto flag will now need to be mounted from the frog, rather than the carriage holder.
This requires drilling out to accomplish. Best way I found was to take the bed off of the frog, move the axis to it's 'zero' position, and drill a hole roughly where the opto flag should be in contact with the opto. If you drill a couple of millimetres closer to the opto that's fine, as you can trim the flag to get it right.

Same as the original, but with a flat top and a small lip to stop it slipping off the jar. I plan to make a few variations and set them side by side to see which is the best...

title: Retro Playstation Pi Usb Hub Holder

description.text:
Scope

This is a usb hub holder for the original Playstation 1 case.

About

I was building a Playstation Pi Retro console, but wanted have usb ports on the back as well, to connect wireless receivers. Therefore I designed this outlet to hold a little usb hub. It fits the playstation casing perfectly. In order to have the corresponding space for the usb-hub I removed the ethernet cable as well es analog audio jacks, from the original Playstation Pi design.

Usage

The hub will be connected to one of the USB-Ports of the Raspberry Pi, while one of the inner usb connections of the hub will be redirected back to the front panel. Therefore you do not loose any of the four front facing USB-Ports, even though the Raspberry only has 4 ports total.

Additional parts

I used the following usb-hub as inlay for this part:

  • USB 2.0 Hub Smile 4-Port

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
Cover for OneplusX, looks like cheese if you print it in yellow. Leaves all the buttons, the camera and the charging connector easy to access. It can fit a round magnet (from AUKEY) to attach the phone to a magnetic holder for car mounting.
I had to cover the speakers on the bottom, otherwise, the side would have been too fragile, it's not impacting loudspeaker too much and anyway I mostly use Bluetooth speakers while driving.
It's my first project, just to learn how to model something around an existing object.
I printed it in PLA, it requires a bit of care when putting the phone inside it, but didn't break even when I applied a bit of force. Borders are a bit too sharp, but it's easy to smooth them with a cutter.
Version 2 has rounded edges.

title: Eachine Wizard X220 - Camera Mount (Foxeer Legend 2)

description.text:
Camera Mount designed for Eachine Wizard X220 - 30 degree camera angle. I mount a Foxeer Legend 2. I've uploaded 2 versions of the STL file. The first one is in default units of Inches whereas the one ending in "mm" is in default units of mm.

Make sure the size when printing is 43.71mm (1.72") x 26.39mm (1.04") x 51.68mm (2.03") (XYZ)

Hope you find this useful! I've printed in both ABS and TPU.

print_settings.Notes:: Use a flexible filament. I used Sainsmart TPU.

description.text:
Very simple design to raise the prop a tad bit on the Eachine X73S. I noticed that my props, if pushed all the way down, would hit against the LED on the arm. Simple fix: this prop riser makes sure there is about 2mm sitting on top of the motor shaft so the prop can never go that low.

I printed using a flexible filament, which I would recommend. This part will grip the shaft and shouldn't drag on the frame if positioned slightly above. If you are not using a flex filament, I am not sure how well this would work, because it might not grip the shaft quite as well and rub.
